stream_context.summary: Kaze demos a new Sauraen-built trace/profiler to understand RTYI’s frame timing, then iterates on Course 13’s snowman cave/slide difficulty and imports a large batch of Biobak’s updated “Oily Boily Bay”/industrial-area assets. The stream focuses on performance (materials/bones/fog, RSP/RDP timing) and on fixing gameplay/behavior bugs (Wiggler pathing + facial phases, collision/step issues).
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces a major new profiling tool from Sauraen, documents concrete N64 performance constraints (idle time/memory wait, RSP/RDP bottlenecks, material/bone budgets), and captures multiple actionable fixes (Course 13 slide memory/collision constraints, Wiggler pathing bug) plus a big asset integration pass from Biobak that pushes an area toward 30 FPS.

findings.summary: Sauraen provided a new combined trace+profiler visualization tool that exposes per-thread/frame time slices (idle, scheduler, VI manager, RSP task, audio). Kaze uses it to reason about unexpected scheduling behavior (game loop running at the end of the frame) and suspects a missing “RSP done” signal as a cause for odd blocking.

Profiling indicates RTYI spends ~25/33ms per frame idling (~76% of frame time), interpreted as CPU time waiting (likely memory/IO/scheduler constraints) rather than doing useful work. Kaze sees surprising time in scheduler/VI manager and notes audio interrupts VI manager.

Kaze observes the RDP running longer than the GFX/RSP work in the trace and interprets it as a bottleneck signal (“we’re RSP bottlenecked”), prompting focus on render-cost reductions (materials, CI/RGBA choices, fog, geometry simplification).

Course 13 contains a “snowman path” leading into a “snowman cave” where the player dodges snowman attacks; Kaze references a Jolly Roger Bay-like climbing/dodging feel. He adjusts the encounter/slide readability because the section felt ‘a little too difficult’.

Course 13’s large slide previously caused a hard memory crash due to Mario 64 collision partitioning: collision triangles crossing multiple grid cells require extra surface nodes, and the slide’s size generated too many allocations. Solving it led Kaze to implement a memory allocation approach he recently discussed publicly, yielding ~400 microseconds of compute-time savings.

To make the slide section fairer, Kaze considers camera solutions but prefers not to tilt the camera. He tests a practical fix by scaling the slide geometry down so the camera horizon is higher and hazards are visible earlier.

RTYI’s input/angle precision differs from vanilla SM64: Kaze says SM64 uses 4096 angles while RTYI uses 65336, making controls ~8× more precise. As a result, existing precision-jump setups/strats (e.g., carpetless-related setups) may not behave identically.
findings.quote: In Mario 64 you have 4096 angles. In this game you have 65336 angles… The controls are about 8 times more precise.

findings.summary: A performance-motivated trig change (switching from lookup tables to a polynomial approximation for arctan/sin/cos) unexpectedly improved accuracy as well as speed; Kaze frames it as a speed optimization that also increased control fidelity.

Biobak delivered a large asset update pack for the industrial/oily area, with explicit optimization notes: fewer materials, fewer bones, updated geometry/collision, and texture changes (e.g., baked helmet strap into texture to save a material; both legs using one bone to save a bone). Kaze treats these as directly tied to hitting 30 FPS.

Kaze believes the Biobak asset optimizations (notably reduced bones/materials across multiple actors like Womps/Koopas) are enough to reach/hold 30 FPS in the oily/industrial level area. He validates render-cost choices (switching CI→RGBA16 where appropriate, adding fog) and flags clipping/collision regressions to fix.
findings.quote: Dang, I think we can get Oily Boily Bay at 30 FPS now.

findings.summary: Fast64 exporter/tooling issues recur: Kaze notes fog preview bugs, auto-picked texture formats (CI vs RGBA) choosing incorrectly, and a case where props/prim color settings appear to export incorrectly, forcing manual investigation and re-linking armatures/material settings.

Kaze fixes a Wiggler movement/pathing bug after discovering his own confusing waypoint logic: he had treated waypoints as “jumps,” causing skipped points and erratic turning. Removing the unnecessary skip logic stabilizes path following; he then adds/validates facial animation phases via bit/popcount-style phase selection.
findings.quote: No wonder that was confusing… there was no reason for this to exist, so now it’s just removed.

findings.summary: Kaze is in paternity leave with a baby overdue by ~2 days; he jokes about spending leave optimizing N64 tech and references time-slicing dev/family life (short work bursts). He shares the planned child name ‘Reyna’.
Kaze remarks that emulator load times can misrepresent console behavior: he says console loads are shorter and emulators emulate N64 lag inaccurately, affecting perceived pacing during testing.

Kaze reiterates a pragmatic, iteration-first approach: he accepts shortcuts/sequence breaks as “part of the fun,” and repeatedly chooses cheap, high-impact fixes (scale geometry, reduce materials, bake details into textures) to preserve playability and performance on real hardware.
findings.quote: Shortcutting is part of the fun.

biobak.summary: Sends a major asset update set for the oily/industrial level (Womps/Koopas/props) with optimization-focused change notes: reduce materials, reduce bones, bake helmet strap into texture, align geometry/collision to the new look, simplify polygons/triangles.
biobak.quote: Made both legs use the same bone, saves one bone. Baked helmet strap into the texture saves one material.

biobak.summary: Provides visual redesign passes (tox boxes fit the world better; updated textures; new glass texture; character face variations like Wiggler faces), pushing a more cohesive construction/junkyard/industrial aesthetic.

Flags specific rigging/export constraints: certain models shouldn’t be merged because it breaks helmet shading; some elements must be linked to the armature; supplies triangle/material counts to keep budgets in check.
biobak.quote: Don’t merge it; it fucks up the helmets shading. Needs to be linked to the armature.

zeina.summary: Is present in chat; Kaze notes Zeina is producing 3D models for a new overworld entrance while he tries his own pass at building the new overworld.
zeina.quote: Zeina is making a bunch of 3D models and stuff… I wanted to give making the new overworld a try.

zeina.summary: Family dynamic appears via joking about Zeina and the baby name ‘Reyna’ (planned).

findings.summary: Created the new trace/profiler tooling Kaze uses to inspect N64 thread scheduling (idle/scheduler/VI/audio/RSP), enabling deeper performance diagnosis and optimization decisions.
Attempts to help debug Blender/Fast64 export issues around normals (“set normals to zero”) and exporter behavior; Kaze directly asks Lilaa how to force zero normals export.

key_stories.title: Adopting Sauraen’s trace/profiler to find real bottlenecks
key_stories.summary: Kaze showcases a new trace/profiler that breaks down frame time by N64 threads and tasks. It reveals that most of the frame is spent idling and that scheduler/VI/audio interactions are nontrivial, reshaping what he thinks needs optimization.
key_stories.challenge: Understanding where RTYI actually spends time on real hardware and why some tasks appear to run longer than expected.
key_stories.process: He limits/unlimits FPS to compare behavior, inspects idle vs game loop placement, and hypothesizes about blocking (including a potentially missing RSP done signal).
key_stories.outcome: A clearer roadmap for optimization: reduce RSP/render load, investigate scheduler/VI time, and validate synchronization signals.
key_stories.key_quote: 25 out of 33 milliseconds are spent on a while 1 loop. It’s all idle.

key_stories.title: Course 13 slide: memory crash, then difficulty/readability tuning
key_stories.summary: A large slide section in Course 13 originally crashed due to collision surface-node allocations exploding as triangles crossed many collision cells. After solving the memory allocation issue (and gaining measurable compute time), Kaze revisits the slide’s fairness and readability.
key_stories.challenge: Fitting large, smooth collision geometry into SM64’s surface-node memory constraints while keeping the gameplay readable.
key_stories.process: He explains the collision cell mechanism, references a new allocation approach, then reduces perceived difficulty by scaling the slide so hazards are visible earlier rather than changing camera tilt.
key_stories.outcome: Slide no longer crashes and plays more fairly; remaining work includes texturing and polishing spikiness/camera feel.
key_stories.key_quote: Because the slide was so big I had to allocate so many surface nodes that the whole thing just crashed.

key_stories.title: Biobak’s asset optimization pass pushes the oily/industrial area toward 30 FPS
key_stories.summary: Biobak delivers redesigned and optimized actor assets (Womps/Koopas/props) with fewer bones, fewer materials, and baked details. Kaze integrates them, adjusts formats/combiners/fog, and notes both visual improvements and performance gains.
key_stories.challenge: Getting a visually dense industrial level to run at 30 FPS within N64 RSP/RDP/material limits.
key_stories.process: He audits material counts, switches CI/RGBA where needed, enables fog for cohesion and cost, and fixes regressions like clipping/collision and animation blockers.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze expects the area to hit 30 FPS “pretty easily,” with follow-up tasks to fix clipping and remaining export/tool quirks.
key_stories.key_quote: It’s like 10 fewer bones total across all of the Womps. Yeah, that helps a lot.

key_stories.title: Wiggler pathing bug caused by confusing waypoint ‘jump’ logic
key_stories.summary: Wiggler behaves erratically (turning early, wandering) due to how Kaze implemented waypoint advancement. Debug printing reveals waypoints were being skipped under certain distance/velocity conditions because waypoints were treated as ‘jumps’.
key_stories.challenge: Stabilizing an NPC path-following system that regressed without obvious recent changes.
key_stories.process: Kaze instruments the logic (prints waypoint values), reasons about sentinel end markers (-1), and removes the unnecessary skip behavior that advanced the path incorrectly.
key_stories.outcome: Wiggler follows the intended path and facial animation phases work as expected.
key_stories.key_quote: See, that’s why the path was so buggy at first because I was skipping waypoints.

key_stories.title: Toolchain friction: Fast64 export, normals tricks, and shading issues
key_stories.summary: Kaze hits recurring export/shading problems (props/prim color appearing wrong, normals tricks no longer working in F3DEX3 due to auto-normalization, and fog/shade combiner tradeoffs). He tries scripts and solicits community help before finding simpler fixes (e.g., checking missed settings, linking armatures).
key_stories.challenge: Keeping a Blender→Fast64→ROM pipeline stable while pushing new rendering tech (F3DEX3) and strict performance budgets.
key_stories.process: Attempts Python scripts, tests split normals, revisits combiner math, and validates in-engine results; he acknowledges prior tricks may be invalid with F3DEX3.
key_stories.outcome: Some issues resolved (missed checks, quick armature linking), but exporter reliability and shading constraints remain ongoing risks.
key_stories.key_quote: Sauraen said you can’t actually use this trick anymore in F3DEX3 because it auto-normalizes.
